transcript.text: Good afternoon everyone and welcome to
the public communication lecture in the
unit and of course this is the event
open to all uh everyone and so we are in
a science week and we were thinking uh
it would be great for everyone to have
an opportunity to be part of this
meeting and this workshop is the a great
story that is going to be shared with us
and Patricia was in the first lecture
when she said that she has an experience
about above 70 years uh to act as a
science communicator. So I can you can
imagine how great and how valuable it
is. And I guess the story of that um you
know science communication is important
because this week as part of the um
the unit we have if you are here from
the communication for scientists this
this week we are going to practice in
the tutorial activity uh to come up with
our public speaking uh topic. So I guess
we want to know how and what are the
strategies how we are going to grab and
you know audience attention how we are
going to share our science how we should
inspire audience with the science. So I
guess I am trying to talk about all of
this before Patricia start her
presentation because I would like to
make sure that we have more attendees uh
joining us. But I think now considering
the time I think uh we can start and the
meeting is going to be recorded. So
those who joined later or miss this uh
opportunity they can always watch this
recording and listen to the recording
and Patricia it's all yours. Please
introduce yourself and we are here to
listen and of course the way that we are
going to run this workshop is for
Patricia to go and cover this story of
public communication and of course we
would like to have about 10 15 minutes
at the end for your questions. So uh we
are going to collect the question from
the chat or if you have an audio we can
let you to turn on your audio ask your
question and we are here to answer. So
thank you very much Patricia.
>> Okay well my dinosaur and I welcome you
to this talk. Um, and I just basically
would like to give you an idea of how I
got into this and how I uh communicate
with people at all sorts of levels about
the research
that myself and and others are doing
science which is basically critical
thinking. Uh it's uh it's important to
everyone and it gives them a power that
otherwise they would lack. So let's go
through. I'm going to give you an idea
of how I got into it and hopefully it
will have lots of uh offsprings
uh for you to think about. So this is my
own personal journey. Um, I grew up on a
farm and I was so lucky to have done
that because as I say, life began with
grasshoppers. And so I was born in 44
and I the first memories that I have
basically is being fascinated with the
environment around me on a farm in
California. Um, there was all kinds of
things there and I shocked my uncle one
time who was a boat builder because he
wanted to build me a dollhouse and I
thought that was fantastic. So at four
he built me a a really big dollhouse
that you could walk into. It was almost
like having uh a living room. And and so
he did that and he came over to see how
I was going to outfit it. And he was
totally and utterly shocked when he
looked in because there were no dolls
and there were no ovens and there no
anything except there were shelves and
shelves of bottles with dead insects in
them. And what I had been doing was
looking at the biodiversity during that
time. The other aspect of my life that
makes it very interesting to me is that
I'm part indigenous. It's Cherokee. It's
not an Australian indigenous uh family,
but on the other hand, I do have a lot
of indigenous friends here. And that
background gave me a different look on
history from the history we were getting
in schools. And one of the things that
has come out of that as I've grown is I
work in many different areas. and I uh
basically learn about their history, be
it people that have been there the
longest or people that have come in
later and I build those into stories for
kids so that they get the whole ring of
history. So, uh let's just look at some
pictures that relate. I mean here is me
at about uh four or five and I'm really
really interested in dirt and so what I
have what I'm doing here is this is
where we we had gone fishing and I was
as fascinated by the sand and the
different kinds of sediments that were
around there. My parents were farmers.
They didn't know anything about this
other than how well it grew plants but I
was interested in that. And so here are
my mom and in the top left, my mom and
grandma on one side of the family which
is mainly Irish and my grandpa and
grandma on the other side on the right
hand side and my grandpa was full-blood
Cherokee. My grandma was English. It was
quite an interesting combination and
they had 13 children and my dad who was
the oldest was the one who raised most
of them. This is the country we grew up
in and this is during the winter when we
had plowed it up. Now I learned how to
drive a tractor very early on. So I
actually learned about the mechanics of
tractors and of what the best way is to
uh plow fields were. I learned something
about the soils and water supplies. All
of those things really were useful. In
addition to the farm, we were
fascinatingly
surrounded by biodiversity.
That big redwood on the right hand side
grew up in the mountains behind where we
lived. Uh the big rocks in Euseimde
National Park which is in California. I
was fascinated with their granit and I
was fascinated with their shapes and
their composition even as a small child
and I didn't have anybody teaching me
about geology but later on that
fascination was very useful when I went
away to university and on the coast
there the California coast we had a
completely different kind of rock setup
it was uh the remains of an old trench
where one continent was going under
another and so the rocks were
serpentinonites they were not granite
They were very different. And I just
noticed all this as a kid because we
went fishing up in the uh the redwoods
in the Sierras. Uh we went hiking in the
you know in the area around Euseimde. We
went deep sea fishing and clamming over
on the coast. I mean we were pretty
self-independent with regard to food we
grew and food we gathered.
Uh we were also on the western part of
California there were oil fields. And I
remember as a f as a kid four or five
years old wondering well what where is
this coming from. So the curiosity that
my parents and my teachers instilled in
me was very very important to me
learning about a lot of things and also
getting to the point where I could ask
questions and not feel like I was being
stupid and I wasn't treated that way. I
was treated as your question is
valuable. Uh we'll try to answer it.
will answer it in a way that you can
understand. And so that that was there.
So I got the farm farmer's ideas. I got
the honey honey people's ideas about how
their bees uh got all the honey together
that was on our farm. I got my teachers
who had a variety of backgrounds. It was
just wonderful to be treated as a in a
way like a colleague rather than
somebody who was missing something. All
right. So, I grew up in an absolutely
wonderful time because it was a time
there was a space race going on between
the Russians and the Yankees. Um, there
were uh there was just we were out of a
war. We we had some small wars. They
weren't small, but in comparison to
World War II, they were small. and uh
and we had just a lot of opportunities
at that time in the 50s and early 60s
for getting a free education. I mean, I
grew up on a farm. We basically, you
know, we weren't big farmers and we
didn't have lots of money and neither
one of my dad was he had to drop out of
school in grade six so he could help his
parents raise their kids. My mom wanted
to go to university, but she was not
offered the opportunity to go to
university. her brothers were, but her
father didn't think girls should be
going to university.
So she in a way when I did go away to
university, she came away with me to
university at the uh University of
California and she got a job in the uh
department of enemology there because
she was a very very good bookkeeper and
just a very good organizer. And they
were so cool that they allowed her as a
person who just had a quotes just had a
high school education to go and sit in
on a number of the um lectures that were
going on. Some of whom were being some
of which were being given by Nobel
laureates at the University of
California at Berkeley. So she got her
education later. But my parents with
that kind of a background they still
wanted to support me going to
university. They had to sell everything
they owned in the way of property
which wasn't a lot. and we all moved
away to university together and so that
was the way it was. Now as I said UC
Berkeley had a lot of Nobel laureates we
were taught by those people um and it
was fantastic to have that kind of a
background and then um I went I got did
my PhD my masters and PhD at Colombia.
So we got a really good background from
many many different kinds of uh
researchers etc. And we also were going
to Colombia at the time right at the end
of Berkeley and the beginning of
Colombia at the time of the plate
tectonics revolution. You couldn't ask
for a better time quite frankly. Um this
is high school. One of my projects that
I worked on was trying to uh build a
radiocarbon dating machine. And again,
one of the things I learned as a farmer
is that don't be afraid to ask questions
and don't be afraid to uh do something
that somebody might tell you is
impossible. What I did as a 14year-old
is I uh I was really interested in
carbon 14 got dates on when things
happened in the past. And so what I did
was to um I just wrote to the man who
was who had invented the technique uh
Willard F. Libby who was at UCLA as a
14-year-old. And I wrote to him and I
said, "Could I come down and see how
your technique works?" And he he wrote
right back to me and said, "Yep, come
down." And I spent a week in his lab at
UC UCLA and I actually ended up building
a carbon 14 machine. Of course, it
wasn't of the quality that Libbyy's was,
but in actual fact, it worked. and I
built it. Um, I had a quotes boyfriend
at that time who was a boy friend and he
was an electronics technician and so he
helped me with the electronics. My dad
was a mechanic and I needed wheel
weights in order to make my um, lead box
that I could put my geer counter in. And
so there we go. And here I am at one of
the science fairs and standing next to
me is Glint T. Seabborg who was the head
of the at um atomic energy commission at
that time being one of the judges. We
were so lucky to have those kinds of
contacts and we were just farm kids and
so you know I think very lucky then I
went to Berkeley um and I started my
degree with my parents being there and
us all working so we could survive but I
didn't have to pay for my education. it
was free and this fella was one of the
graduate students there and I thought he
was pretty cool and so we ended up
getting hitched and he is Tom Rich who
is now the curator of paleontology at
the museum Victoria and we've worked on
research ever since but we cross paths
first at UC Berkeley then we went to uh
the American Museum of Natural History
and Colombia and there we were caught up
in the uh plate tectonic revolution
which was going on at that time And
again I think I keep emphasizing this
that
we were taken as colleagues. We were not
treated as you know uh minuscule
students or something like that. And I
think that is really important for
people to realize that that is the best
way to teach to communicate uh to get on
with people. And I remember my childhood
uh we when we were on the farm we had to
have workers coming in from Mexico. They
were picking grapes. I would go out in
the field and pick grapes with them. I
learned their language. Some of the
words I got in trouble for learning
because they weren't exactly the words I
thought they were. But we all looked
upon each other as equals and we had
stories to share and we respected one
another and we got on with it. And I was
respected as a little kid and they were
respected as people that were coming
into the country for just for work um
etc. And I that is something that has
stuck in my mind forever and it I just
wish it was there in everybody. Here
were some of the maps that we were uh
helping develop. We actually were
working with the team at uh Lamont Lab
up in north of um New York City who were
doing the cross the the sea uh the
surveys that were going on about
earthquakes, about hotspots, about all
of this. this was coming in and we were
actually engaged with those scientists
um Sykes and and all these people that
were working on developing these these
uh models which now are just taken
pretty much for granted. They those were
underdevelopment when we my when Tom my
husband and I were students and we were
involved in actually helping develop
those. One of the things that I um when
I was in university at Colombia, I was a
I was a geologist. I was being trained
as a geologist and a paleontologist. But
I didn't feel like I uh knew enough
about the modern world other than the
farms in California and some of the
eastern uh Appalachian areas etc. and
maybe a few of the places in Wyoming and
c in the deserts of um the central US.
And there came an opportunity. And this
is another thing I would put out. Just
keep your eye out for opportunity. It
may be odd. It may be you may get an
idea that maybe you're not qualified to
do it or you're not going to be allowed.
But here again, there was an ad that
went out by a group that was working in
Costa Rica, which is a Central American
country, on having a two-month course
down there, and there were only 20
people going to be picked from around
the United States. And I was told by
many people, you don't have a chance.
You just don't have a chance. Well, what
happened was I used the term I'm a
paleontologist and there was nobody else
that applied that was a paleontologist.
Most everybody in it were really modern
biologists. So I got in and it was
really as it said a mind expansion for
me to understand the modern world and I
ended up publishing a couple of papers
with one of my um my professors on
pollination biology and looking at how
plants and animals develop co-evolved
systems. One of them was fantastic
because it was this little uh
hummingbird that kept flying around all
over the place and we were trying to
figure out what this hummingbird did for
a living. And so I was given one project
to go and sit by this plant which I sat
by for a week before I figured out what
was going on. And what would happen
is this plant was nice and green. But
when it started to bloom, the the the
flower itself turned very the leaves
outside the flower started to have get
red spots on them. And as those red
spots got redder and redder, the little
hummingbird would come around and say,
"Aha, underneath there is a flower and
it's got some it's got some juice in it
that I want to get. Um, and I'll go in
there and get some of that juice." But
as it was getting the the juice, it got
some pollen knocked on the front of its
head. And so then it went to the next
plant. And so it was pollinating. And
that was a system that must have
developed over millions of years. and as
a student and studying the divi the ver
the biodiversity there that led to a
paper and an understanding of something
that nobody had understood before. So if
you get an opportunity to do something
that may seem impossible or that may
seem like maybe only on the edge of what
you're interested in, think about it and
don't be discouraged by people saying,
"Oh, maybe you you probably won't get
it." Because that's not not necessarily.
And this was Costa Rica. I did a lot of
other things down there. learned a lot
of of things from people, the the guide
that was driving the ox cart. Um, I got
enough Spanish that I could speak with
some of the folks and I learned all
about their history and I learned I just
learned so much in two months that I I
really look at it. And this is just us
flying in in a DC3
and the pilot on that plane who dropped
us down in southern Costa Rica said,
"Get everything out of this plane.
Nobody goes back with me. The only way
I'm going to get off this airirstrip is
to have the plane as light as possible.
And another time, uh, one of my
colleagues and I decided we wanted to go
across the Panameanian border.
We wanted to see how the vegetation
changed. The only way we could get
across was on horseback. So, we managed
to rent a horse for a bottle of rum. And
we spent two days going and and taking
making maps of the area that we were
working in to the southern part of uh of
uh Costa Rica across into Panama. And
also there was a geologist on our team
and we went and looked at all of the
geological phenomenon around there. Just
a huge variety of life, a huge history
of how that part of the world formed.
You can
imagine how much we gained. And this was
the paper that we published showing
hummingbird seeing the red spots and
knowing it was time to go and get his
juice um and also pollinate.
The next thing that happened when I went
to um I started working on puzzles from
central Australia
um when I was at at Berkeley and I
started working under a man by the name
of uh Ruben Arthur Sturin and
unfortunately he died while I was still
his student and I went to another
professor at Berkeley and unfortunately
he didn't ma he didn't last so I was
beginning to think I was bad luck.
However, I was allowed to take all of
the material of the fossil birds that
Stern had collected
in the 50s and 60s and take it to the um
uh the museum in uh uh in the at the
American Museum of Natural History. And
that was my PhD thesis and it led me to
Australia. That was the first time that
I came to Australia and I decided I
wanted to stay. So we um Tom and I both
were able to come on an expedition in
the very early '7s to go to the
localities where some of this material

Queensland and places like that. And
that really just turned my interest on
this beautiful, beautiful country and
the material that it had. Here is
Sturton uh on the right uh in his

standing sit well crouching next to him
is a guy called um Paul Lawson. Paul
Lawson is still alive. He's 103 and we
just published a paper with him about
two years ago. So he has had a long
history in working on the paleontology
of this country. And what was so
interesting when I did this thesis was
it the desert above is what it's like
today, but 20 million years ago it was
like that in central Australia. And
that's what came out of my work uh on
the fossil plants and on the birds in
particular. Uh and and we found so much
stuff. It was just mindb boggling what
hadn't been found and what hadn't been
reported. And so u 20 million years ago
there were flu well as little as two
million years ago there were flamingos
all over the place here in Australia.
Now they're gone. The big bird on the
bottom there is a thing called a
drummerid and those birds were dominant
herbivores. All of that stuff that was
the discoveries and just to find
something and be able to report on it
and think about it is amazing. And how
you communicate that then which is what
I'm talking about is you there's many
many different ways. One of the ways of
one of the big lizards that we found was
to put together exhibitions and to have
the scientists deeply involved in
putting the exhibition together the kids
obviously they are fascinated with it.
And so then you start asking the kids to
think about well why the teeth and does
does it have permanent teeth? And
there's just all sorts of questions that
you can ask people, kids, everybody to
think about when they see some of these
discoveries. We've also, Tom and I both
have been so lucky to work with Peter
Trustler who is an artist who did a Ph
did a PhD with me. Um, and artwork is
absolutely gripping. Uh, you might get
something in the fossil record that, you
know, is a bit of this and a bit of
that. You know, you might have a leg and
you might have some teeth and you might
have some vertebrae.
uh and by aligning that with something
that's as close in the living world as
you can with this thing in the past and
then putting together a reconstruction
uh you grab people's attention you get
an they get an idea that you can talk in
words but if you have a really good uh
photographic reconstruction almost that
helps a lot
well one of the things that I became
interested in
again which led to a lot of science
communications led to
exhibition that I put on up in so up to
New Guinea and you take a boat and you
take it across to uh Java, you find the
the the biota on both sides of what's
now as many names, but one of them is

And again, it led to so much science

Southeast Asia and Singapore,

interpretations can change. If you've

Okay. So that's gives you an idea of the

Uh that was more important than money.
it was more important than position and
fortunately we had the we had the Tom
had a job so at least one of us had a
job and then after a while and we were
settled and um I had a part-time job and

it's time time for kids and so that's

and they were safe and they were they
were
they had full-time in the dinosaurs of

down in the arts was one of the places
that we spent a fair few years in the
70s and 80s. Uh, this is a little bit

Dinosaur Cove was we finally got a

unique. They're polar. Uh, and that claw

Uh Lee Allen is our daughter is in the

uh was these we had them in the field

Underground work at Dinosaur Cove was it
was challenging and we managed to do it

because the friends of the museum
Victoria and the National Geographic

dinosaurs. We've got the greatest

being. It doesn't matter what your

um I think I I might go on now for about

um funding and traveling exhibitions uh
